Basically, it indicates that we had major imbalances build beginning in the turn of the century where the U.S.
took its consumption share of GDP to an unheard of 72 percent.
At the same time, China under consumed, over saved and drove its growth engine by a combination of extraordinarily unprecedented powerful increases in exports and fixed investment.
And I think it's fair at the G-20 to raise questions about the character equality of another growth recipe for the world, post-crisis, rather than just focus on growth itself.
But how would you do something like that?
I mean, how would you get a country like China or the United States to shift their values and to make that kind of rebalanced decision?
What would you have to do?
Well, in America, unfortunately it's already been done.
The handwriting is on the wall.
We have consumers with record debt, totally inadequate saving, given the retirement imperatives of 77 million baby boomers.
We have weak income.
We've had a job shock.
We have an unemployment rate of 9.7 percent and rising, and all the bubbles have supported the consumer from equities to residential property have burst.
So the American consumer can see the handwriting on the wall, and the adjustments are now beginning.
So the American consumer is basically being scared straight here.
Well, it's not just scared straight but there's this fair amount of fear at work.

But the actual sustenance of excess consumption has been withdrawn so American consumers really don't have any choice, for the first time in generations, other than wean themselves from this spending binge, the likes of which no major economy has ever been on.
What about China and its production binge?
Well, China's got, you know, really the opposite problem.
And the main story in China here is that this massive nation of 1.3 billion consumers is scared to spend.
They're scared to draw down their excess saving.
And the reason they're scared is because there's been a lot of turnover in the Chinese labor market due to the reform of once state-owned enterprises.
And they've done these reforms without really giving workers the safety net that they used to have under the old state-owned regime.
So they need to build a safety net.
They need to invest in social security, private pensions, medical insurance, unemployment insurance.
They have made only tiny steps in that direction.
They have to make big steps.
And when they do that, I think the insecurity over future income and job prospects will begin to subside, and Chinese households will step up in a more broadly based way and support their economy.
